newsitem.title: GERMANY: German industry welcomes Spain's Eurofighter move.
newsitem.headline: German industry welcomes Spain's Eurofighter move.

text.p: Germany's main aerospace industry group, headed by Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG (Dasa) chief executive Manfred Bischoff, on Friday welcomed Spain's decision this week to order 87 Eurofighter combat aircraft.

Spain has joined Britain in declaring it would fund serial production of the 21st-century fighter by a four-country consortium starting next year, but a strapped German government is still in talks on funding.

"The pressure among European partner countries is mounting on the federal government...to take the overdue decision to release enough funds in the 1997 budget," Bischoff said in a statement by the German Aerospace Industries Association.
Britain has already said it would buy 232 out of a total production run of 620 Eurofighters, and Spain has decided now to commit 25 billion pesetas ($195 million) to the project in 1997.
The spending is being funded by a credit from the Spanish industry ministry to the defence ministry repayable from 2002 onwards, the statement said.
The total Spanish financial commitment to the Eurofighter project will be 980 billion pesetas, guaranteeing the future of 22,000 skilled jobs in Spain.

Germany intends to buy 180 Eurofighters -- 140 fighter combat jets and 40 fighter-bombers -- but talks are continuing on price. Dasa has warned that a delay in placing a firm order could lead to an explosion in project costs.
Defence Minister Volker Ruehe said on Thursday in India that talks on Germany's procurement of the Eurofighter were still going on.

"Especially the question of money we can use for the Eurofighter in the next four years...I will negotiate until I have satisfactory results. I can only spend the money I have. We need a plane and we want it to be a European plane," he told reporters in New Delhi.
German newspaper reports have said that Ruehe has only offered 100 million marks ($65.6 million) for Eurofighter next year, while the plane's builders want a minimum payment of 392 million marks.
Die Welt newspaper said on Friday that the government was under increasing pressure to agree on a proposal ahead of a key sitting of parliament's budget committee on November 14.
Dasa, which will make the fuselages of the Eurofighters, has a 30 percent stake in the project. British Aerospace owns 37.5 percent, Italy's Alenia Spa 19.5 percent and Spain's Casa 13 percent.
-- Douglas Busvine, Bonn newsroom, 49-228-26097150 ($ = 128.3 Spanish Pesetas) ($ = 1.524 German Marks)
